description.text: On this textile label from Alexander Drew & Sons, a battlefield scene can be seen. Rama on the right, on a chariot, is seen battling Ravan on the left with his multiple heads. Rama's army comprises of monkeys, who sent his troops out to fight the demons of Ravan on the upper right side. The armies fight each other with bows and arrows, swords and lances.

inscription.text: Alexander Drew & Sons. Ram Chand Seal & Co.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: Textile label by Alexander Drew & Sons

ext:item.ext:value: text-en: Alexander Drew & Sons. Ram Chand Seal & Co.
text-hi: राम चान्द सील एन्ड काः

description-en: On this textile label from Alexander Drew & Sons, a battlefield scene can be seen. Rama on the right, on a chariot, is seen battling Ravan on the left with his multiple heads. Rama's army comprises of monkeys, who sent his troops out to fight the demons of Ravan on the upper right side. The armies fight each other with bows and arrows, swords and lances. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Among the first examples of bazaar art are the pictures accompanying bales of textiles to be sold, a practice that may have begun sometime in the 1860s or ‘70s. These pictures served as means of quickly distinguishing one manufacturer from another, with images presumably helping to overcome challenges of literacy and linguistic difference as the goods traveled from producer to wholesaler, retailer and consumer. These pictures often bore no connection to the products sold; for example mythological imagery was often used to identify one brand of textiles as against another. The British companies selling these goods presumably treated the images simply as ways of promoting their products, rather than as either expressions of their own beliefs, or as endorsements of the beliefs of their customers. (Arvind Rajagopal)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: With Ravi Varma’s influential breakaway from the depthless, two-dimensional convention of god-portraiture, where space was structured according to cosmic hierarchy, the rules of classical perspective came to be applied equally to deities and laity. Instead of always presenting deities looking frontally at the viewer with an all-seeing gaze, according to custom, mythological characters began to appear in meditative poses, turned away from the viewer, absorbed in themselves like mere mortals, as aesthetic rather than devotional figures. (Arvind Rajagopal)(gs)
related literature: Freitag, Sandria B. 2002. “The realm of the visual: Agency and modern civil society.” in: Contributions to Indian Sociology. 36 (1 & 2). pp.: 365-397. (gs)

related literature: Masselos, Jim 2006. “A goddess for everyone: the mass production of divine images,” in Jackie Menzies, ed. Goddess Divine Energy. Sydney: Art Gallery of New South Wales and Thames and Hudson. (gs)
related literature: Rajagopal, Arvind 2010. "The Commodity Image in the (Post) Colony" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/100/index_1.html fig.9 (17.1.2011)(gs)

Among the first examples of bazaar art are the pictures accompanying bales of textiles to be sold, a practice that may have begun sometime in the 1860s or ‘70s. These pictures served as means of quickly distinguishing one manufacturer from another, with images presumably helping to overcome challenges of literacy and linguistic difference as the goods traveled from producer to wholesaler, retailer and consumer. These pictures often bore no connection to the products sold; for example mythological imagery was often used to identify one brand of textiles as against another. The British companies selling these goods presumably treated the images simply as ways of promoting their products, rather than as either expressions of their own beliefs, or as endorsements of the beliefs of their customers.

With Ravi Varma’s influential breakaway from the depthless, two-dimensional convention of god-portraiture, where space was structured according to cosmic hierarchy, the rules of classical perspective came to be applied equally to deities and laity. Instead of always presenting deities looking frontally at the viewer with an all-seeing gaze, according to custom, mythological characters began to appear in meditative poses, turned away from the viewer, absorbed in themselves like mere mortals, as aesthetic rather than devotional figures.
